calendar_xml:id.p: The Julian calendar, as used in England before 1752. The year starts on March 25.

A Hebrew calendar dating from the creation of the world, based on biblical genealogy. The start date varies according to the biblical texts used. Here, based on the dates given for the same events in other formats, this calendar starts in 3962 BC.
A calendar dating from the Roman discovery of Britain. Based on the dates given for the same events in other formats, this calendar starts in 50 BC.

list_rend.item_xml:lang:
Si illud ex quo causatur nobilitas, vt
Regnum Ducatus Comitatus &c de= scendit ad posteros tunc in infinitum
erit ille nobilis ad quem transit
ipsa nobilitatis causa
The heade manour of a Baronye
(in
Bractons
tyme) could not be
dismembred by dower if there were
sufficient besides because it was
the countenance of a Baron.
The kinge may geve the yongest dowghter:
in Mariage (with the whole Barony
to one of his knightes if the rest of
the dowghters in their fathers lyfe
were bestowed.
Yf the Emperour signify his bare plesure
that he will have any person to be a
genttilman that is
not
none; not
mentioning his heires. yet that
quality shalbe interpreted to reache
to his children Quia nobilitas
politica est haereditaria
Women are capeable of Duchies
Counties Baronies. &c in their
owne righte, & may transmitte
thesame to theire heires.
Theire husbandes also are capeable
of thesame in their wives righte
Armes & styles are thinges inhe= ritable
Queene Elizabeth's:
mother was created
Marchionesse of Pembrooke & her
sonne (if he had married a subiect)
should have been marquess.
Yf any say that dignities descend not vnto
women, then must the most Auncient Earles
doe away theire Tytles
Some have had .2. Baronies descende
vnto them at once: as the: Earle: of Lyncolne
had Clynton & Saye./
Richard: Hastinges
had welles & willoughby
This is a principle that the name of a
kinge, duke, Earle, Baron & suche
like is Res indiuidua. Therfore the
style of Viscount Lisle descended to sisters
was extinct & at the Prynces disposi= tion.
Viscountes are of later tyme & have their
Creations by patent with Anuitye
The Common lawe dealeth little with
rytes & customes of Chiualry: but such
questions have beene alwayes decyded
before the Constable: & Marshall of England:
in
ffrance
women succeed their Ancestours
aswell in dignities as in patrimonies
The Custome of euery Region is the Rule
of those thinges
By the custome of
England
the husband
of a Baronesse by byrthe shall vse the
stile of her Barony duringe her life.
And if he be Tenant by Curtesy. then
for terme of his owne life.
The Lawe grantinge the more which is the
Barony, denieth not the lesse which is the
dignity. a thinge incident vnto it.
The husbande by Lawe hath no right in his
wyves inheritance but only in respect
he is a husbande: but having a childe
he hath acquired an estate in Lawe
& is admitted to doe homage & not before
The Crowne of
England
is out of the
curtesye.
None may vse his wives style but suche as
by the curtesy of
England:
hath right to her
posessions for terme of lyfe.
The Title cannot descend to a collaterall
heire.
The Lawe requireth the seruice of the
woman: of her husbande.
Landes geven to a man & his heires male of his
body who hathe heire female & no male
& she hathe a sonne: he shall not inherite
because he cannot deryve hymselfe from
the male but by the woman.
The Common Lawe is Custome & in these
thinges contrary to the customes of other Regions
The Common Lawe taketh no knowledge
of questions of chivalry.
Prescription worketh a state of inheritance
in Lawe in Barons & baronies which in
Lawe worketh a ffeesymple.
feetaile is not an inheritance by the demise
of the Lawe: but of particuler persons.
Yf the dignity of a Baronesse be in the wife
as inheritance, then thesame inheritance
must be denied in the husbande in the righte
of his wife: & her name must be vsed
in theuery writte, vpon suite for thesame in= heritance
An Auncient
place
Barony may be geven
to a Baron of newe creation the place
beinge voyde & in the kinges handes by
attaynder.
There is difference betweene Creation
restitution
By writte implicatiue inheritance passeth
to the partie to whom thesame is directed which
must be intended a ffeesymple. vnlesse the
woordes or olde vsage enforce the costomes.
Liberum maritagium are properly no woordes of
inheritance: neuerthelesse by approved
custome, they are receaved to employ
inheritance.
In a gifte of ffranke mariage there must
be kynred betweene the donor the woman
donee.
And it is called ffranke because it is free
from all seruice except ffealty. vntill the
4th degree.
Service of Barons is imediatly dewe
vpon his creation.
A Barony descendinge to more then one
dowghter heire is extincte
A man marryinge the sole heire of a Baron
may vse the style of dignity by the generall
custome of this Realme.
If a man prohibited by the kinge forbeareth to
vse the style. yet the right remayneth.
The Lawes of this Realme enhableth
the husband (by the woman) to vse the
stiles of dignity.
As for theire honours sake they wolde not
vsurpe these Titles: so wold not kinges
in all Ages (without iust cawse) have
tollerated it.
Tytle by prescription is so stronge that none
learned can deny thesame.
Studentes neede iudgement in reading.
to discerne of speaches spoken at random
from those that be grounded vpon the
Comon Lawes of the Realme./
To trye the trewthe, we must examyne
it by the generall Rule maxime of the
Lawe.
Euery woman by her mariage loseth the proper
name of the ffamily wherin she was
borne: for by that act she incorporateth
her selfe in her husbandes ffamilye
In this Realme euery woman retayneth
her name of dignity she had before
mariage: vnlesse a greater happen
vnto her, then the greater is preferred
that other suppressed, but not extin= guished.
An Exigent may ^
not
be awarded against
an Earle: for the dignity of hys
name.
The Lawe denieth not to women the
pryveledge they have by their hus= bands. Vxor enim gaudet viri Pri= vilegiis.
An Earle is priueledged because
he is a Lord: of the Parliament.
It is (of some) doubted whether an
Earle in respect only he is a dukes
sonne may clayme that
benefite of
priueledge.
To doubte whether awoman may use
the name dignity
of
she ^
receaveth from her
husbande
is to doubte of the equitie of the
Lawe.
The Lawe that bereaveth the wife of her
names receaved of her owne howse
ought to endowe her with all her hus= bandes Tytles.
Women are denied the name of theire
husbandes dignities that are annexed
to administration.
Yf names of dignities are extincte
in women: then conveighances ffyines
passed by those names should be vtterly
voyde: but in deede are not./
In makinge of writtes: the common Lawe
determyneth not of rightes of names
of nobility. but only of the vse of them
to avoid confusion of names in writtes
and pleaes, which require euery thinge certen.
These woordes quae fuit Vxor Comitis: Arondel:
determineth not or taketh awaye her
Dignitye: but declare a determination
of the mariage betwixt the Late Earle
her.
Women may vse names of dignities and
they are not loste by non vse in Courte.
The writte that expresseth her not Coun= tesse intendeth her Countesse
The Courte laboureth only to conserve
forme of proceadinge not to determyne
of the meere righte of dignities.
These Woordes Nobilis ignobilis doe
not alwaies signify (as in our English)
noble not noble; but somtyme, gentill:= man or gentill:woman, no gentill:man or no
gentill woman. Therfore this sayinge in
the Ciuile Lawe . Quod mulier nobilis
nubens viro ignobili desinit esse no= bilis . must be vnderstood if gentill:wo= men marry with suche as are no gentill= men./
Brooke
in his Abridgment noteth that by
our lawe a woman so marryinge loseth
no dignity.
Men lyvinge at
Roome
are subiecte to
Romish Customes, in
Englande
to En= glishe. /
Aunciently in
Roome
the husbandes dig= nity was communicable to the wife and
from the ffather to the sonne nephew
no farther then vsque Pronepotem ./
The dowghter: of a Senator marryinge with
a commoner lost her nobility or gene=
rosity: vntill the Comoners obtayned that
out of the body of them; Senatores might
be chosen: Then if she maried with suche
a one as by his qualitye might be chosen
Senator, she had favour
The Romans after xpian faithe receved
publication of mariage (in the Lord
to be: honourable: to all persons, they soughte
Goddes children before the children of
kinges to be their sonnes in Lawe.
By a Romayne constitution it was pro
vided that
if
euery noble or gentillwoman
stayned with vnchastitye should
Sose
lose her Nobility. And this carrieth
greate reason with it; for the forfaiture
is for a most filthy vnnoble fault
when thother is not only for no fault but
for an honorable action.
ffeodale dignities are not tyed to the
person but to the ffee in theire first
creation, that is to the dukedome
Marchionate County or Baronye.
Vnlesse the ffee be forfaited there can
be no forfaiture of the Name.
No gentilman beinge called to serve the
Kinge a Latere scilicet in neerest place
of service is therby made a gentill man./
Hostienses
: saieth that somtymes that by custom
the husband shyneth with his wyves ~
beames. As when a symple soldiour
mar
marieth with a Countesse
